bestBHT.bht: After Jesus had been tempted by Satan in every possible way, the enemy was ultimately defeated. These temptations expressed Satan's desire to make Jesus draw back from the horror and agony of the Cross, but Jesus remained steadfast. Satan departed, waiting for another opportune time, which some speculate could have been in the garden of Gethsemane. Jesus' triumph over temptation reveals his unwavering strength and faithfulness.

Henry Alford: 13.] for a season: see on Matthew, ver. 11, and note on ch. xxii. 53.
Marvin Vincent: The temptations formed a complete cycle, so that it could afterward be said of Jesus that 'he was in all points tried like as we are' (Hebrews 4:15)."
More strictly, until a convenient time; since Satan meant to assail him again.
Philip Schaff: Had completed every temptation. Not so definite as Matthew, who shows how the third temptation (second here) ended in the withdrawal of Satan.
Until a season, an opportunity, a convenient season. Probably referring more particularly to the closing scenes of our Lord’s life, when the agency of Satan (in Judas) is asserted.
See chap. Luke 22:3; Luke 22:53; John 14:30; comp. John 8:44, where the opposition of the Jews is ascribed to the devil.
Archibald T. Robertson: These three kinds exhaust the avenues of approach (the appetites, the nerves, the ambitions). Satan tried them all.
The enemy tried all his weapons, and was at all points defeated.
In Gethsemane the devil tried to make Jesus draw back from the culmination of the Cross with all its agony and horror.
John Gill: When he had tried every way, and all sorts of temptations with him; and when he had done this, 'in', or 'with all his power', ... 'and profited nothing'; could not succeed, or get any advantage over him."
He departed from him for a season; till another opportunity should offer, or till that time should come, when would be the hour and power of darkness.
By means of one of his disciples, he should bruise his heel, and bring him to an accursed death.
John Wesley: A convenient season — In the garden of Gethsemane, Luke 22:53.

bhtAttempts.bht: After Jesus had been tempted by Satan in every possible way, the enemy was ultimately defeated. These temptations were a comprehensive cycle that allowed Jesus to experience the same trials as humanity. However, Satan had not given up entirely, but merely departed until another opportune time. One insightful commentator noted that in the garden of Gethsemane, the devil attempted to make Jesus draw back from the horror and agony of the Cross. Yet, Jesus remained steadfast in his purpose, and the enemy failed to gain any advantage over him. Truly, Jesus' victory over temptation is a testament to his strength and faithfulness.

After Jesus had been tempted by Satan in every possible way, the enemy was ultimately defeated. These temptations expressed Satan's desire to make Jesus draw back from the horror and agony of the Cross, but Jesus remained steadfast. Satan departed, waiting for another opportune time, which some speculate could have been in the garden of Gethsemane. Jesus' triumph over temptation reveals his unwavering strength and faithfulness.

After Jesus had been tempted by Satan in every possible way, the enemy was at all points defeated. Satan tried all his weapons, but was unable to gain any advantage over Jesus. Although Satan temporarily departed, he was still waiting for another opportune time to try to make Jesus draw back from the agony and horror of the Cross. Jesus' victory over temptation stands as a testament to his strength and faithfulness, as he endured the trials that all of humanity faces.

After Jesus had been tempted by Satan in every possible way, the enemy was at all points defeated. Satan tried all his weapons, but was unable to gain any advantage. Although Satan temporarily departed, waiting for another opportune time to make Jesus draw back from the agony and horror of the Cross, Jesus' victory over temptation remains a testament to his strength and faithfulness. He endured the trials that all of humanity faces and emerged triumphant.

After Jesus had been tempted by Satan in every possible way, the enemy tried all his weapons and was defeated at all points. Even though Satan temporarily departed, he awaited another opportune time to make Jesus draw back from the anguish and dread of the Cross. Nevertheless, Jesus' triumph over temptation stands as a testimony to his strength and steadfastness, for he underwent the trials common to all humanity and emerged victorious.
